content:
I guess reverse would be fun. I just had it fastest, and it is a quite long story for basically checking for any occurrences of vv or ^^ - while I still have no idea what I actually did.

Your solution code seems to grasp the details you meant with this clash. However, it can also be solved with removing all spaces and | from input, and then looping by two and saving any vv or ^^. That gave me 100%, but I have no idea how it relates to your statement story (which sounds rather interesting).

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I didn't know almost nothing about orbitals, so solving this puzzle like reverse was the easiest way for me, a regex was enough for it.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy enough for a clash puzzle: fastest and shortest.

I also had atomic orbital lessons, and I read the description before : this is why I cannot really say if it would fit the reverse mode. I would say yes, but only real condition will reveal it.

Interesting idea, solvable in 5 mins. Upvoted.
Suggestion: One may want to specify that the solver has to print the orbitals which violate the principle from left to right, e.g. in test 4, the answer is ^^ vv ^^ vv ^^ instead of other permutations.
Reverse mode: In fact the solver does not need to know anything about atomic orbitals when solving - they just need to know they will output all occurrences of ^^ or vv. So I think its not as hard as stated below..?

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solvable in under 5 minutes, even under Reverse conditions.
I was able to solve it only looking at the test cases (Reverse conditions), but it wasn't easy and I have a physics background. Reverse could be too hard for most clashers, worth considering just limiting to Fastest/Shortest. Solvable in 5 minutes with description for most coders on the site, I'd think.

Forgive me if any of my points below are wrong, because I know nothing about atomic orbitals.

Goal
* Please change "(for example," to ", for example," (you missed the closing bracket; but I guess it's better to just replace the opening bracket with a comma).

* Aren't the orbitals separated by {{|}} instead of spaces?

* Why is there an empty space character in the example? Isn't that an "unfilled space", which should be marked by an underscore instead?

* Please change "signs (if" to "signs. If", and then "ignored)" to "ignored." with a full-stop. That's a main rule and shouldn't be put inside brackets (which seem to denote secondary/unimportant information).

Input
* Aren't the orbitals separated by {{|}} instead of spaces?

Constraints
* Just leave the section blank if there are no constraints.

Thanks.

Input says orbital *groups* are separated by spaces. The goal should be changed, though.
More importantly, cases like _^ and _v are treated inconsistently by the goal and the solution. The goal states that they're correct, but the solution rejects them. This could be important for optimizing in shortest mode.

As for the goal. yes, it's pretty much what leetcod said, the orbitals are in groups and separated by spaces. You can see an example here if you scroll to the end:
https://chem.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Introductory_Chemistry/Introductory_Chemistry/09%3A_Electrons_in_Atoms_and_the_Periodic_Table/9.06%3A_Quantum-Mechanical_Orbitals_and_Electron_Configurations

And yeah, I'll change the other errors, I guess I forgot to notice them üòÖ

Thank you.

Wow. OK, I got it now. It was very confusing to me because the use of the | character was not explained in the statement.

Could new cases with more than 2 orbital groups be added then?
Possibly, although it wouldn't make much of a difference ü§∑
Oh, I realized that I forgot to include the "__" orbital type, added it now üëç
Agreed that it wouldn't make much of a difference. The most important thing is to explain what "|" is.
Also @leetcod, just saw what you said at the end, added the extra notice üëå
It's not only important for shortest mode; it's necessary to know that _^ and _v are not present (or are correct or incorrect) to ensure that any solution in any mode is correct.
